Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for the conference "International Conference in Approximation Theory" that will be held from May 8 - 11, 2017 at Georgia Southern University.

The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the field of approximation theory. A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF and the like an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at: https://sites.google.com/a/georgiasouthern.edu/approximation-conf/

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The conference brought together established and new researchers, including advanced graduate and undergraduate students, for exchange of ideas and discussions of recent developments in the wide field of mathematics encompassed within the approximation theory subject. This conference provided opportunities for young researchers to learn from leading experts the background and latest developments in the subject and to further their knowledge of the field by interacting with more experienced mathematicians. The sessions were planned such that talks by established researchers were interspersed with time for the follow up questions and discussions. The invited lectures delivered by eminent mathematicians provided an opportunity to broaden ones knowledge of the field. 

Broader Impact:

The conference brought together a number of experts in the theory of approximation, post docs, and graduate students in an effort to promote advances in the area, in particular to young mathematicians. It was a great networking opportunity for junior faculty and for graduate students, who had a first hand opportunity to further their knowledge of the field by interacting with established researchers. We especially encouraged the participation of women and otherwise members of minority groups. Among other activities, the conference hosted a panel on the subject "Women in mathematics". The moderators included well established women mathematicians (Olga Holtz, Martha Abell) as well as a junior faculty (Ha Nguyen). The figures attached show the count of participants in different categories. More than 50% of participants were non-senior faculty, with a 16% women participants out of plenary speakers. The young researchers participation stands at 37%. We have made an effort to balance the list of speakers in terms of geographic locations. We had 9 speakers from the US, 2 from Canada, 5 from Europe (Poland, Spain, Ukraine), and 1 from the Middle East (Israel). We had 3 female speakers.  Among 13 poster presenters there were 2 females and one disabled person. Participation by country includes US, Austria (2), Canada (3), Israel (1), Poland (1), Russia (1), Spain (1), Ukraine (6), India (2).     

We plan to disseminate broadly the results by publishing the proceedings of the conference. We had preliminary discussions with Springer Publishing Company.
